metadata.sermon_start_end: I have said before that New Testament people wrestled with an enlightened, pagan world for the souls of men and women and in so doing they seized vocabulary for the faith [...] Now the fever of this life, until the kiss of eternal health is upon our brow! Now we weep, until God himself shall wipe all tears from our eyes! [...] He will claim us from 'will call.'
metadata.liturgical_context: Sunday Service at Concord Baptist Church of Christ
metadata.historical_context: Late 20th century (approx. 1980s). Context of the Black Homiletic tradition in Brooklyn, NY, bridging classical rhetoric with contemporary urban life.
metadata.notes: The sermon is a prime example of the 'Old School' African American pulpit tradition, characterized by rhythmic cadence and vivid metaphorical 'reframing' of commercial language.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: Taylor excels in what Paul Scott Wilson calls 'painting the picture.' He takes the abstract commercial term 'earnest' (arrhabōn) and translates it into the contemporary urban experience of 'Down Payment' and 'Will Call.' The imagery is sensory and varied, moving from the 'stench' of the marketplace to the 'music of old ocean' and the 'autumn winds blowing leaves.' He avoids 'telling' the congregation that God is omnipresent; instead, he 'shows' them by imagining the gospel tattooed on leaves or skywritten in the heavens. This creates a cinematic quality where the hearer is not just listening to a lecture on Ephesians but is visualizing the cosmic reach of grace. The metaphors are living and culturally situated, particularly the 'mink coat' anecdote which serves as a concrete anchor for the theological concept of the 'already but not yet.'
quotes: He might have written, put it like you want, tattooed, cut, carved the word of the gospel in the leaves of the trees.
As the waves everlastingly pound against the shores and the great breakers roar in and out.
Now the fever of this life, until the kiss of eternal health is upon our brow!
strengths: Masterful use of 'show, don't tell' regarding God's communication.
Cultural contextualization of biblical commercial terms into 'Will Call' departments.
Sensory appeal through auditory (ocean roar) and tactile (kiss of health) language.
improvement_points: The 'mink coat' metaphor, while vivid, carries materialistic baggage that might distract some hearers from the spiritual 'inheritance'.
Some metaphors (leaves blowing) are slightly traditional; more gritty urban imagery could further sharpen the 'reframing'.
The transition between the 'skywriting' imagination and the 'internal witness' could be more visually bridged.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: Strongly weighted toward 'showing.' Taylor spends significant time building imaginative scenarios before stating the theological conclusion.

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: Taylor demonstrates high 'stewardship of language' (McEntyre). He is remarkably precise in distinguishing between the building and the church ('Concord Church did not burn. The building... burned'). He consciously 'baptizes' secular vocabulary, showing a high awareness of how words function. He avoids 'Canaanite jargon' by taking the heavy word 'predestination' and immediately translating it into 'neighborhood expressions' like 'when your number is up.' This precision makes the theology accessible without diluting the complexity. However, there is some rhetorical repetition ('millions and millions and millions') which, while effective for oral delivery, slightly reduces the economy of the written text. His use of 'unsmart' and 'hearable' shows a playful yet deliberate stretching of language to capture the congregation's attention.
quotes: Concord Church did not burn. The building in which Concord Church met burned.
Somebody is called upon to make God's Word 'hearable.'
That's a neighborhood expression of predestination.
strengths: Clear distinction between theological concepts and folk-expressions.
Avoidance of dusty jargon through creative neologisms ('hearable').
Careful definition of 'the church' as people rather than an entity.
improvement_points: Occasional use of 'filler' phrases ('I guess we would all have to admit') could be tightened.
The transition from the barber shop anecdote to the theology of predestination is slightly wordy.
Some gendered language ('souls of men and women, boys and girls') is repetitive in its attempt at inclusivity.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Theological jargon (predestination, earnest) is present but always immediately deconstructed and 'reframed' into common parlance.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The sermon is a rhythmic tour de force. Taylor utilizes classical rhetorical figures like anaphora ('If he has fixed us... if he has straightened us... if he has lifted us') and antithesis ('upside down... right-side up') to create a cadence that builds emotional momentum. The sentence structure varies between short, punchy declarations and long, flowing lyrical passages. This is clearly 'oral language' designed for the ear, following the 'musicality' criteria of Grözinger. The use of alliteration and parallelism ('fever of this life... kiss of eternal health') creates a 'legato' feel in the conclusion that contrasts with the 'staccato' of the barbershop dialogue. It possesses a natural 'flow' that makes the written text feel like a musical score.
quotes: If he has fixed us when we were out of fix, if he has straightened us out when we were bent and crooked, if he has lifted us when we were down.
The Lord will provide! Has provided! Does provide!
Now the night, until the morning comes! Now the fever of this life, until the kiss of eternal health is upon our brow!
strengths: Expert use of repetition and parallelism to build rhetorical power.
Strong variation in sentence length that guides the listener's breath.
Poetic quality in the 'peroration' (conclusion) that sticks in the memory.
improvement_points: The opening paragraph is slightly more 'academic' and less rhythmic than the rest of the sermon.
The 'barbershop' section slows the rhythm significantly; while good for narrative, it loses the 'cadence' of the previous section.
Ensure the 'rhythmic build' doesn't lead to predictable patterns that the audience can tune out.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Purely oral language. The text is clearly designed for performance and rhythmic delivery.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The poetics of this sermon are exceptional. Taylor demonstrates a masterly grip on the 'musicality' of the English language, utilizing the Black Homiletic tradition's emphasis on cadence and imagery. He successfully 'reframes' abstract Pauline theology into the sensory world of the hearer. By moving from the 'marketplace' to the 'ocean' and finally to the 'Will Call' window, he ensures the 'Word' is not just heard but seen and felt. His stewardship of language is evident in his refusal to hide behind jargon, choosing instead to 'baptize' everyday speech for sacred purposes.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a clear 'Homiletical Plot' (Lowry). It begins with an 'upsetting of the equilibrium' by introducing the difficult and often feared word 'predestination.' Taylor creates tension by contrasting the 'far out' doctrine with 'neighborhood expressions.' The movement is a journey from human responsibility (hearing/believing) to divine assurance (sealing/claiming). There is a palpable turning point when he shifts from what *we* must do to what *God* has done (the 'Down Payment'). The energy builds toward the end, moving from the 'marketplace' of the world to the 'Will Call' of eternity. While it has elements of a 'points' structure, the narrative flow of the 'contract' metaphor keeps it from feeling static.
quotes: Now, hearing that word, predestination, do not let your minds wander off...
There is a part we must play in the plan of salvation...
Let me quickly bring you to the other side [of the contract].
strengths: Effective 'hook' using a controversial theological term.
Clear movement from the 'trouble' of human limitation to the 'grace' of divine completion.
Strong use of the 'contract' metaphor as a structural spine.
improvement_points: The transition between the 'responsibility' section and the 'God's payment' section is a bit abrupt ('Let me quickly bring you...').
The barbershop anecdote is slightly long and risks losing the theological thread.
The 'three-point' logic (hearing, believing, sealing) is visible; a more seamless narrative weave could enhance the 'opera aperta' quality.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: A dynamic journey structured around the metaphor of a commercial transaction.

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: This is the sermon's greatest structural strength. Taylor achieves a profound 'reframing' (Cilliers) by placing the 1st-century Mediterranean marketplace alongside the 20th-century Brooklyn marketplace. He respects the 'strangeness' of the biblical text (the commercial origins of 'earnest') while making it startlingly relevant through the 'Will Call' metaphor. He connects the 'enlightened pagan world' of Ephesus to the 'unsmart' modern world of Lynchburg and Brooklyn. The integration is organic; he doesn't just 'apply' the text at the end, but allows the text's own imagery to dictate the contemporary illustrations (the mink coat, the bank, the barbershop). He successfully moves the hearer from 'then' to 'now' without losing the 'there' of the gospel.
quotes: They seized vocabulary for the faith... from the whole system of Mediterranean commerce.
All of these old doctrines sift down into the street where we live.
She said... 'I paid down on a new mink coat and I must go to Will Call and pick it up.' Well, the Lord has paid down on us.
strengths: Brilliant 'reframing' of the Greek 'arrhabōn' into 'Will Call'.
Seamless movement between the biblical world and the hearer's daily life.
Honors the historical context of the text while asserting its present power.
improvement_points: The discussion on predestination (1 Tim 2:4) could be more deeply integrated with the Ephesians text itself rather than just countering it.
The 'ocean' and 'wind' imagery feels slightly disconnected from the 'commercial' theme established at the start.
Could explore the 'pagan world' context more to parallel modern secularism.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: Yes. The sermon offers a new frame: our lives are a 'purchased possession' currently waiting in the 'Will Call' of God's providence.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: In terms of Ciska Stark's 'open work of art,' the sermon is somewhat 'closed' but leaves room for the 'mystery of the between.' Taylor uses a fairly authoritative 'preacherly' voice that provides clear answers. However, he maintains openness by acknowledging the 'already but not yet' tension—the fact that God does *not* yet have full possession of our lives. He respects the 'ambivalence of existence' (fever, weeping, infirmity) without resolving it too cheaply. The ending is a 'promise' rather than a 'possession,' which leaves the hearer in a state of hopeful waiting. However, the rhetorical force is quite directive, leaving less room for 'resistance' or alternative interpretations than a more 'polyvalent' sermon might.
quotes: Now you and I know that the Lord does not own us fully yet.
Now the night, until the morning comes!
The Lord has paid down on us... but the transaction is not finished.
strengths: Honest acknowledgment of the 'not yet' of Christian experience.
Invitation to the hearer to see their own story within God's 'contract'.
Ends on a note of 'trust' rather than a rigid moralistic checklist.
improvement_points: The rejection of predestination is quite categorical; more room for the 'mystery' of God's sovereignty could be left open.
The 'responsibility' section feels a bit prescriptive ('If you walk up and down... you are failing').
Could use more open-ended questions to invite the hearer's own interpretation of 'earnest' in their life.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: Primarily a 'closed' work of witness, but with 'open' windows into the tension of the 'not yet'.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The dramaturgy is robust and effectively paced. Taylor uses the 'commercial contract' as a macro-structure that holds the various narrative elements together. The integration of text and context is a highlight, demonstrating a sophisticated 'reframing' of ancient vocabulary for a modern urban audience. While the sermon is rhetorically authoritative (leaning toward a 'closed' work), it sustains the existential tension of the 'already but not yet,' creating a 'space for grace' that is both comforting and challenging.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: The sermon largely avoids religious kitsch. Taylor does not offer 'immediate comfort' or 'pre-chewed emotions.' He takes the 'pain of suffering' seriously in the final movement, acknowledging 'fever,' 'weeping,' and 'infirmity.' The 'mink coat' story risks kitsch due to its materialistic nature, but Taylor uses it as a gritty, real-world analogy for a sophisticated theological concept rather than a sentimental 'happy ending.' He avoids the 'clichéd story' by grounding his witness in the 'marketplace' and 'barbershop'—places of reality rather than stained-glass piety. The emotion feels authentic because it is tied to the struggle of 'not being fully possessed' by God yet.
examples_of_kitsch: The 'legend' of the angels and Jesus is a borderline kitsch trope common in homiletics, though Taylor uses it to emphasize responsibility rather than mere sentiment.
The 'mink coat' imagery could be seen as 'prosperity kitsch' if not carefully handled.
authentic_moments: The admission that 'the Lord does not yet have full possession of your life and he does not have full possession of my life.'
The description of the 'fever of this life' and the 'waves everlastingly pounding'.
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: To further distance from kitsch, avoid the 'angel legends' and lean more into the raw 'neighborhood expressions' and the 'groaning' of the creation mentioned in the broader Pauline context.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: Taylor opens a significant 'Space for Grace' (Cilliers) by emphasizing that the 'seal' is a 'promise' and not a completed work. He avoids 'dogmatic sealing' by admitting the current incompleteness of the believer. However, the first half of the sermon leans heavily on 'human responsibility,' which risks closing the space with moralism. The balance is restored in the second half where the 'Divine Actor' takes center stage, paying the 'down payment.' He sustains the tension between 'already' (the seal) and 'not yet' (the Will Call), which is the essence of Reformed aesthetic grace. He respects the mystery by pointing toward a future 'redemption' that we do not yet fully grasp.
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: Yes, the tension between the 'purchased possession' and the 'Will Call' status is the central theme.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: Partially; while he explains the 'contract,' he leaves the 'completion' as a future mystery of God's claiming.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails in the final movement, though the 'responsibility' section is quite moralistic.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: To increase space, emphasize that even the 'hearing' and 'believing' are enabled by the Spirit's 'down payment' rather than just a human 'contractual' obligation.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is an aesthetically strong example of the 'Reframing' style of preaching. Gardner C. Taylor demonstrates a sophisticated 'stewardship of language,' taking the commercial metaphors of Ephesians and making them resonate with the lived experience of an urban congregation. The poetics are characterized by a rich, rhythmic cadence and vivid, sensory imagery that 'shows' the gospel rather than merely 'telling' it. Structurally, the sermon moves with a clear narrative arc from the 'trouble' of human responsibility and the confusion of 'predestination' to the 'grace' of God's down payment. While it leans toward a more 'closed' rhetorical style typical of the great witness-preachers, it avoids religious kitsch by grounding its hope in the reality of human infirmity and the 'not yet' of the Christian life. It creates a 'space for grace' by framing the Christian life as a state of being 'claimed' but waiting for the final 'Will Call.' The sermon's beauty lies in its 'sober simplicity'—taking the language of the street and baptizing it for the pulpit.
strengths_top_3: Masterful 'reframing' of the commercial term 'earnest' into 'Will Call'.
Exceptional rhythmic and musical quality of the prose (Domain A3).
Authentic integration of biblical world and contemporary urban life (Domain B2).
improvement_points_top_3: Reduce the moralistic weight of the 'responsibility' section to allow more 'space for grace' earlier.
Tighten the narrative transitions between the 'ocean/wind' imagery and the 'commercial' theme.
Increase 'polyvalence' by using more open-ended questions for the congregation.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Fits the 'Imagery' focus of Paul Scott Wilson and the 'Reframing' focus of Johan Cilliers.
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Aesthetically appeals to hearers who value narrative, rhythmic delivery, and the 'translation' of high theology into everyday 'neighborhood' wisdom.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with more 'staccato' rhythms in the opening to mirror the 'marketplace' energy.
Use a 'reframing' metaphor that is less materialistic than a 'mink coat' to avoid 'prosperity' connotations.
Allow the 'silence' of the 'not yet' to speak as much as the 'rhetoric' of the promise.
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: Gardner C. Taylor’s sermon is a high-caliber aesthetic event. It succeeds because the 'how' (the rhythmic, commercial metaphor) is perfectly wedded to the 'what' (the theology of the Holy Spirit as a pledge). It avoids the pitfalls of dry intellectualism and shallow kitsch, offering instead a 'sober beauty' that honors both the biblical text and the hearer's reality. It is a model of how to 'care for words' in a way that opens a space for the Holy to happen.
